questions.text: Which of the following is the correct presentation of Bernard–Soulier syndrome?

choices.text: Presence of large platelets with thrombocytopenia and defective platelet adhesion
Small platelets, eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia due to an X-linked disorder
Umbilical stump bleeding on day 1 of life
Normal platelet count with defective platelet aggregation caused by absent GPIIb/IIIa receptors

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Presence of large platelets with thrombocytopenia and defective platelet adhesion

  • Remember Big Bernard implying big platelets in Bernard–Soulier syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by deficiency of GpIb receptor Platelets hence cannot bind vWF leading to defective adhesion. Peripheral smear shows giant platelets with thrombocytopenia.

Incorrect options

Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is X-linked disorder: triad of eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia with small platelets. Bleeding is due to low platelet count, not platelet adhesion defect.

Factor XIII deficiency presents with umbilical stump bleeding in neonates (day 1–2 of life), poor wound healing, and recurrent intracranial hemorrhage. PT, aPTT, BT all normal. Only clot stability is affected. Clot solubility test in 5 M urea or 1% monochloroacetic acid: clot dissolves and is diagnostic. Factor XIII assay confirms deficiency

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive defect of GpIIb/IIIa receptor and platelets cannot bind fibrinogen and leads to defective aggregation.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the mechanism of action of Ticagrelor?
questions.solution: Correct answer is a: Inhibiting P2Y12, ADP receptor

questions.text: Life span of platelet in body is
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: 7-10 days

Life span of platelets

Physiological in body

7-10 days ( no consumption and no alloimmunization)

Storage in blood bank at 20-24 C

3-5 days

Special situations like DHF, DIC

24 hours
  • Platelets are disc-shaped, anucleate cells < 5 μm that circulate in the blood at concentrations of 200–400,000/μL.
  • Platelets are derived from megakaryocytes, polyploidal hematopoietic cells found in the bone marrow.
  • The primary regulator of platelet formation is thrombopoietin

questions.text: A 30 year old multigravida post-partum female developed multiple bruises and ecchymosis after delivery. coagulogram shows prolonged aPTT, normal TT and normal PT. and TT and a mixing study that does not correct with normal pooled plasma. The Bethesda assay using factor-specific deficient plasma is planned. First differential diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c; Acquired Hemophilia A

Post-partum women can develop autoantibodies against factor VIII. This causes isolated prolonged aPTT that fails to correct on mixing study, and diagnosis is confirmed with a Bethesda assay.

Incorrect options

Von Willebrand disease: Also prolongs aPTT, but mixing study corrects since it is a deficiency, not an inhibitor.

HELLP syndrome: Presents with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and thrombocytopenia

DIC: Causes both PT and aPTT prolongation with low fibrinogen and thrombocytopenia

questions.text:
Which of the following cause/s lead to DIC?

a. Fulminant hepatic failure

b. Acute promyelocytic leukemia

c. Carcinoma prostate

d. Fungal sepsis
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: a,b,c,d

Sepsis is overall the most common cause. Any agent whether bacterial, viral and fungal can trigger DIC

In Fulminant hepatic failure production of both pro-coagulant and anti clotting factors will reduce leading to DIC.

Auer rods of APL trigger DIC. Carcinoma prostate and pancreas release tissue factor (thromboplastin-like material) and procoagulant phospholipids that lead to DIC.

questions.text: 9-year old with acquired factor IX deficiency. However, the coagulation abnormality corrected after administration of Vitamin K. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: Bile duct obstruction

  • Acquired factor IX deficiency can occur in Vitamin K deficiency because factor IX is a Vitamin K–dependent clotting factor (along with II, VII, X, and proteins C & S).
  • Now the correction with Vitamin K strongly suggests that this is not true factor IX deficiency (i.e. Hemophilia B, which does not correct with Vitamin K), but rather a Vitamin K deficiency state.
  • In children, bile duct obstruction (cholestasis) causes fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption. This causes Vitamin K deficiency that will reduce the levels of factors II, VII, IX, X and cause prolonged PT/PTT, which corrects with Vitamin K.

questions.text:
Which of the following are used in non transfusion therapy for hemophilia A?

a. Factor VIII concentrate

b. Cryoprecipitate

c. DDAVP

d. Epsilon amino caproic acid
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: c,d

The question is on non-transfusion therapy that uses DDAVP and Epsilon amino caproic acid.

DDAVP: It causes a transient rise in FVIII and VWF, but not FIX, by release from stores in vascular endothelial cells.

EACA: antifibrinolytic therapy prevents destruction of already formed clots by plasmin.

questions.text: Which clotting factor has the longest half life?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: 13

Factor VIII has the shortest half life of 4-6 hours and factor XIII has the longest half life of 11-14 days.

questions.solution:

The image shows solitary basophilic inclusion inside RBC which is Howell jolly bodies. Option A is seen in Neutrophils. Option D is seen in plasma cells. Option B is multiple bodies inside RBC.

Döhle bodies are pale blue-gray, oval inclusions in the peripheral cytoplasm of neutrophils, representing aggregates of rough endoplasmic reticulum and ribosomal RNA. They are typically seen in toxic systemic states such as bacterial infections, burns, and pregnancy

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent skin and respiratory infections since infancy. Examination reveals partial albinism and peripheral neuropathy. Peripheral smear is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying defect?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Defective lysosomal trafficking

  • The slide shows giant granules in the cytoplasm of neutrophil. This along with history of recurrent infections and albinism points to diagnosis as Chediak higashi syndrome.
  • It occurs due to LYST gene mutation on chromosome 1 that leads to impaired microtubule-dependent trafficking of lysosomes. This causes defective phagolysosomal fusion and trafficking inside the neutrophils.

Manifestations seen in chediak higashi syndrome

  1. Giant granules in leukocytes
  2. Recurrent pyogenic infections
  3. Oculo-cutaneous albinism ( defective melanosome trafficking)
  4. Neuropathy

Incorrect options

B. NADPH oxidase deficiency is seen in chronic granulomatous disease and leads to recurrent catalase-positive infections, defective oxidative burst (diagnosed by DHR test).

C. CD18 defect seen in Leukocyte adhesion deficiency. It presents with delayed umbilical cord separation and recurrent infections without pus

D. Myeloperoxidase deficiency is usually asymptomatic, impaired killing of Candida

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about ITP?

choices.text: Secondary ITP occurs due to autoimmune causes like SLE and infections like HIV , HCV
Wet purpura heralds life threatening bleed
Eltrombopag is used in patients who relapse

questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Severe ITP needs emergency splenectomy

  • Emergency splenectomy is not first-line for severe ITP; initial management involves corticosteroids, IVIG, or anti-D immunoglobulin. Splenectomy is considered only in chronic or refractory cases, not as an emergency measure.

Incorrect Options:

Secondary ITP occurs due to autoimmune causes like SLE and infections like HIV, HCV

Wet purpura means bleeding in oral mucosa and it heralds life-threatening bleeding including intracranial hemorrhage.

Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist for chronic/refractory ITP to stimulate platelet production.

questions.text: The following feature is seen in which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: Plasma cell dyscaria

The image shows rouleaux formation which is seen in multiple myeloma/ plasma cell dyscaria.

In multiple myeloma, malignant plasma cells produce large amounts of monoclonal immunoglobulins.

These excess proteins coat the RBC surface, reducing the zeta potential (normal electrostatic repulsion between red cells), so the RBCs stick together in stacks — rouleaux formation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive fatigue, early satiety, and weight loss over 3 months. Examination reveals massive splenomegaly. Laboratory findings: Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL, WBC: 3,000/µL, Platelets: 90,000/µL, Peripheral smear is shown below.. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Myelofibrosis

P.smear finding of tear drop RBC + immature WBC in circulation + pancytopenia + Splenomegaly indicate diagnosis as Myelofibrosis. The reason for splenomegaly is extramedullary hematopoiesis.

The initial impression due to immature cells in circulation and massive splenomegaly and counts can cause misdiagnosis as CML. It does not have “tear drop RBC”.

Option C will have high hemoglobin and option D will have pancytopenia without organomegaly.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Acute promyelocytic leukemia develops bleeding from body orifices. which of the following coagulogram report will be seen in this case

choices.text: PT increased, BT increased, aPTT increased
PT increased, BT normal, aPTT increased
PT normal, BT increased, aPTT increased
PT normal, BT normal , aPTT increased

questions.solution:
Correct answer is a: PT increased, BT increased, aPTT increased

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL / M3 AML) is notorious for triggering acute DIC due to release of procoagulant substances/ auer rods from promyelocytes.

In DIC: PT ↑, aPTT ↑ (due to clotting factor consumption) + Bleeding time ↑ (due to thrombocytopenia/platelet dysfunction).

This explains simultaneous prolongation of PT, aPTT, and BT in such a patient.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications to use of the following instruments in hematology except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D. Low platelet count

  • Low platelet count is often the reason for performing a bone marrow biopsy to determine its cause, and with very low counts platelet transfusion can be given before the procedure.

Incorrect options

Option A and C: Absolute contraindication until corrected because of uncontrolled bleeding risk.

Option B. Local site infection: Absolute contraindication as biopsy can disseminate infection beside increasing risk of osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with petechiae over his legs, pallor and decreased urine output. His mother reports that he had bloody diarrhea a week ago. The examination shows mild edema and hypertension. Laboratory results reveal:Hemoglobin: 7.8 g/dL, platelet count: 65,000/µL, Creatinine: 2.5 mg/dL, Peripheral smear: schistocytes present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is b: Hemolytic uremic syndrome

  • Schistocytes with low platelet count and renal failure ( reduced urine output + Hypertension and oedema ) favours diagnosis as HUS. Platelet count is low due to consumption in formation of microthrombi.

Incorrect options:

A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura : Isolated thrombocytopenia without anemia, schistocytes, or renal failure; no preceding bloody diarrhea.

C. Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura : Shares MAHA + thrombocytopenia + renal signs but usually occurs in adults, with prominent neurological symptoms and no diarrheal prodrome.

D. Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Causes hematuria and hypertension after strep infection, but no MAHA, thrombocytopenia, or schistocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following causes non thrombocytopenic purpura?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is d: HSP

HSP causes purpura due to small-vessel leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA deposition — platelet count is normal (non-thrombocytopenic purpura).

HUS, TTP, and DIC all cause purpura with thrombocytopenia because of platelet consumption in microthrombi or coagulation activation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with severe hemophilia A (factor VIII activity <1%) is scheduled for wisdom tooth extraction. His past history includes multiple episodes of hemarthrosis but no inhibitors to factor VIII. Which of the following is the best strategy to prevent perioperative bleeding?

choices.text: Transfuse fresh frozen plasma 1 hour before surgery
Give prophylactic factor VIII concentrate to raise levels to ≥50% before the procedure
Start oral tranexamic acid only after the extraction

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Give prophylactic factor VIII concentrate to raise levels to ≥50% before the procedure

Incorrect Options:

A. Desmopressin : Useful only in mild hemophilia A or vWD by releasing endogenous factor VIII and vWF

B. Fresh frozen plasma: Contains factor VIII but in low concentration and large volumes would be required

D. Tranexamic acid: Helps stabilize clots but does not replace deficient factor VIII; used only as adjunct

questions.text: 16-year-old girl presents with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding since menarche and frequent gum bleeding after brushing her teeth. She reports prolonged bleeding after a tooth extraction last year. There is no history of joint swelling or muscle hematomas. Examination reveals pallor but no petechiae or ecchymoses. Laboratory results show: Hemoglobin: 9.5 g/dL, Platelet count: 250,000/µL, PT: Normal, aPTT: Mildly prolonged, Bleeding time: Prolonged, Ristocetin cofactor assay: Decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Von Willebrand disease

  • Mucocutaneous bleeding with normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, mildly prolonged aPTT, and decreased ristocetin cofactor activity is classic for vWD due to defective platelet adhesion and reduced factor VIII stability.

Incorrect options

A. Hemophilia A – Causes deep tissue/joint bleeds, not mucocutaneous bleeds with only aPTT prolonged

B. Bernard–Soulier syndrome – Shows thrombocytopenia + giant platelets + absent ristocetin response; here platelet count is normal.

D. Glanzmann thrombasthenia – Normal ristocetin test but absent aggregation with ADP, collagen, epinephrine; not seen here.

questions.text: 4-year-old boy presents with a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds since infancy. His parents report prolonged bleeding after minor cuts, but there is no history of deep muscle or joint bleeds. Examination reveals petechiae and multiple ecchymoses over the extremities. Laboratory findings show:Platelet count: 250,000/µL, PT: Normal, aPTT: Normal, Bleeding time: Prolonged, Platelet aggregation absent with ADP, collagen, and epinephrine; normal with ristocetin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is c: Glanzmann thrombasthenia

  • Mucocutaneous bleeding with platelet aggregation defect: Absent with ADP, collagen, epinephrine, but normal with ristocetin is classic for GpIIb/IIIa deficiency.

Hack to remember

  • GTA- RACE negative : Glanzmann Thrombasthenia has Aggregation with Ristocein but ACE A: ADP , C: collagen, E: epinephrine absent

Incorrect Options:

A. Bernard–Soulier syndrome – Low platelet count + giant platelets + absent aggregation with ristocetin.

B. Hemophilia A – Presents with deep tissue/joint bleeds + prolonged aPTT

D. Von Willebrand disease – Causes mucocutaneous bleeding but shows defective ristocetin-induced aggregation and often prolonged aPTT

questions.text:
Elective splenectomy is done in which of the following conditions?

a. Beta thalassemia major with 50% increase in transfusion requirement over last one year

b. Hereditary spherocytosis with severe anemia by 5 years of age

c. Chronic ITP non responsive to steroids

d. Myelopthisis
questions.solution:
Correct answer is 3: a,b,c

Elective splenectomy is done in:

  1. Hypersplenism seen with beta thalassemia major
  2. HS with severe anaemia
  3. Chronic ITP not responding to medication

Myelophthisis means bone marrow failure caused by replacement of normal hematopoietic tissue with abnormal cells like metastatic cancers ,TB, Sarcoidosis and gaucher disease. It presents with pancytopenia and leukoerythroblastic blood picture (nucleated RBCs + immature myeloid cells in peripheral smear).
